sn17.35:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain, not long after Devadatta had left.
sn17.35:1.2: There the Buddha spoke to the mendicants about Devadatta:
sn17.35:1.3: “Possessions, honor, and popularity came to Devadatta for his own ruin and downfall.
sn17.35:4.1: or a reed, all of which bear fruit to their own ruin and downfall …
sn17.35:5.1: It’s like a mule, which becomes pregnant to its own ruin and downfall.
sn17.35:5.2: In the same way, possessions, honor, and popularity came to Devadatta for his own ruin and downfall.
sn17.35:5.3: So grim are possessions, honor, and popularity.
sn17.35:6.1: That is what the Buddha said.
sn17.35:6.2: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
sn17.35:7.1: “The banana plant is destroyed by its own fruit,
sn17.35:7.2: as are the bamboo and the reed.
